PT J
AN ZOOR15101002158
DT Article
TI A new genus Zahradnikia gen. nov from Taiwan (Coleoptera: Dermestidae:
   Megatomini).
AU Hava, Jiri (jh.dermestidae@volny.cz) 
SO Arquivos Entomoloxicos
VL 9
PS 23-26
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Zahradnikia gen. nov. and the species Zahradnikia taiwanica
   sp. nov. from Taiwan are described, illustrated and compared with the
   similar genera Orphinus Motschulsky, 1858 and Katkaenus Hava, 2006. The
   new genus differs by the structure of its antennae, wings and male
   genitalia.
C1 Hava, Jiri; Czech Univ Life Sci, Fac Forestry & Wood Sci, Kamycka 1176,
   Prague, CZ-16521, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM jh.dermestidae@volny.cz

SN 1989-6581

   region; Eurasia; Asia

TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Dermestoidea,
   Dermestidae
OR Orphinus - Motschulsky 1858 (Dermestidae): [Diagnostic characters, P.
   24]. 
   Zahradnikia (Dermestidae): [Gen nov, Of subtribe Crytorhopalina, Type
   species Zahradnikia taiwanica, p. 24]. 
   Zahradnikia taiwanica (Dermestidae): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 24].

TI Contribution to the knowledge of the Globicornis Latreille, 1829 species
   (Coleoptera: Dermestidae: Megatominae) from Socotra Island (Yemen).
AU Hava, Jiri (jh.dermestidae@volny.cz) 
SO Arquivos Entomoloxicos
VL 9
PS 73-76
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB All based on materials from Socotra Island (Yemen), Globicornis
   (Socotracornis) subgen. nov., Globicornis (Socotracornis) fallax sp.
   nov. and Globicornis (Globicornis) boswelliae sp. nov., are described,
   illustrated and compared with similar genera and subgenera.

PT J
AN ZOOR15011060189
DT Article
TI Lovcenipora iranica nov sp., an unusually large chaetetid sponge from
   the Upper Triassic (Howz-e Khan member, Nayband Formation) of northeast
   Iran.
AU Senowbari-Daryan, Baba (basendar@pal.uni-erlangen.de) 
   Amirhassankhani, Fatemeh
SO Zitteliana Reihe A Mitteilungen der Bayerischen Staatssammlung fuer
   Palaeontologie und Geologie
VL 53
PS 15-22
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Sponges are the most important reef builders in the bio-constructions
   imbedded within the Norian-Rhaetian Nayband Formation at various
   localities exposed in central Iran. Besides sphinctozoans and inozoans,
   hypercalcified sponges, i. e. chaetetids and spongiomorphids, are
   relatively abundant in some biohermal and biostromal reef structures. In
   these reefs, chaetetids are usually small (<10 cm). However, an
   unusually large species was found in the reefs near the village
   Hassan-Abad in the Ferdows area, northeast Iran. This species is
   described as Lovcenipora iranica nov. sp. Associated organisms are
   usually fragments of small-sized dendroid spongiomorphids.
C1 Senowbari-Daryan, Baba; Univ Erlangen Nurnberg, Geozentrum Nordbayern,
   Loewenichstr 28, Erlangen, D-91054, Germany, Germany.
EM basendar@pal.uni-erlangen.de
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Paleontology
SN 1612-412X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Biometrics; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Lovcenipora [Size /  / Systematics] [Iran /  / ] [Triassic / Upper
   Triassic / ]. 
   Lovcenipora iranica [Iran /  / new species] [Triassic /  / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Hydrozoa
OR Lovcenipora - Giattini 1902 (Hydrozoa): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 21; Fossil]. 
   Lovcenipora iranica (Hydrozoa): [Sp nov, Iran, Triassic, P. 18; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR15011060191
DT Article
TI A Middle Cenomanian coral fauna from the Northern Calcareous Alps
   (Bavaria, Southern Germany) - new insights into the evolution of
   Mid-Cretaceous corals.
AU Loeser, Hannes
   Werner, Winfried (w.werner@lrz.uni-muenchen.de) 
   Darga, Robert
SO Zitteliana Reihe A Mitteilungen der Bayerischen Staatssammlung fuer
   Palaeontologie und Geologie
VL 53
PS 37-76
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the Northern Calcareous Alps, relics of a formerly widely distributed
   shallow marine facies belonging to the Brander-fleck Formation (Upper
   Albian to Early Turonian) crop out and contain locally abundant corals.
   The fauna described here derives from Middle Cenomanian sediments. It
   encompasses 39 species in 25 genera, belonging to seven scleractinian
   and one octocorallian order. One genus and two species are described as
   new. The fauna that was formerly located at the northern part of the
   Apulian plate (Austroalpine unit), south of the Penninic ocean, shows
   palaeobiogeographic relationships to Cenomanian faunas from the
   Pelagonium, the Aquitanian Basin, and the Bohemian Basin, indicating
   stronger connections to Tethyan than Boreal faunas. The fauna also
   shares species with Aptian and Albian, as well as Late Cretaceous
   faunas. Ten genera experienced a range extension; five genera have their
   last occurrence in the Middle Cenomanian fauna, and five genera their
   first occurrence. The fauna has an intermediate position between the
   Early Cretaceous and the post-Cenomanian corals showing that the faunal
   turnover at the Cenomanian/Turonian boundary was not marked by the
   sudden appearance of new faunal elements, but the disappearance of taxa.
   Many faunal elements that constitute post-Cenomanian faunas already
   existed in the Cenomanian but were very rare.
C1 Werner, Winfried; SNSB Bayer Staatssammlung Palaontol & Geol & Geob,
   Richard Wagner Str 10, Munich, D-80333, Germany, Germany.
EM w.werner@lrz.uni-muenchen.de
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1612-412X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods;
   Mesozoic
DE Actinastrea; Columellophora; Hydnophora; Leptophyllaraea; Neocoenia
   [Germany / Bavaria / new record] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Cnidaria [Evolution /  / systematics; coral] [Zoogeography /
   Palaeobiogeography / ] [Germany / Bavaria, Northern Calcareous Alps /
   stratigraphical distribution] [Cretaceous / Middle Cenomanian / ]. 
   Eothelia [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Eothelia bavarica; Eothelia hoelzli [Germany /  / new species]
   [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Octocorallia, Zoantharia, Scleractinia
OR Cnidaria (Animalia): [Fossil]. 
   Eothelia (Octocorallia): [Gen nov, Of family Agatheliidae, Type species
   Eothelia hoelzli, p. 52, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Eothelia bavarica (Octocorallia): [Sp nov, Germany, Cretaceous, P. 52;
   Fossil]. 
   Eothelia hoelzli (Octocorallia): [Sp nov, Germany, Cretaceous, P. 52;
   Fossil]. 
   Actinastrea (Scleractinia): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Columellophora (Scleractinia): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Hydnophora (Scleractinia): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Leptophyllaraea (Scleractinia): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Neocoenia (Scleractinia): [Fossil; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15011060191
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15011060192
DT Article
TI A new genus and species of caridean shrimps from the Upper Jurassic
   Solnhofen Lithographic Limestones of Schernfeld (S Germany).
AU Winkler, Norbert
SO Zitteliana Reihe A Mitteilungen der Bayerischen Staatssammlung fuer
   Palaeontologie und Geologie
VL 53
PS 77-83
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and species of caridean shrimps, Schernfeldia schweigerti
   nov. gen. nov. sp., is described from the Upper Jurassic Solnhofen
   Lithographic Limestones of Schernfeld near Eichstatt (Lower Tithonian,
   Hybonotum Zone). It differs from other genera of carideans primarily in
   the shape of the rostrum.
SC Zoology
SN 1612-412X

   species Schernfeldia schweigerti, p. 78, Jurassic; Fossil]. 
   Schernfeldia schweigerti (Natantia): [Sp nov, Germany, Jurassic, P. 78;
   Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR15011060193
DT Article
TI Pygmy moths (Lepidoptera, Nepticulidae) from Baltic Amber (Eocene).
AU Fischer, Thilo C. (thilo.fischer@biologie.uni-muenchen.de) 
SO Zitteliana Reihe A Mitteilungen der Bayerischen Staatssammlung fuer
   Palaeontologie und Geologie
VL 53
PS 85-92
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Pygmy moths (Nepticulidae, Lepidoptera) from Eocene Baltic amber are
   described with five new specimens, representing the only specimens
   beyond one described before. Some of the findings differ from
   Stigmellites baltica Kozlov in species and sex. They are formally
   described as new species Bohemannia butzmanni and B. aschaueri.
   Phylogenetic and paleoecological aspects of Nepticulidae from Baltic
   amber are discussed.
C1 Fischer, Thilo C.; Univ Munich, Dept 1, Grosshadernerstr 2-4, Planegg
   Martinsried, D-82150, Germany, Germany.
EM thilo.fischer@biologie.uni-muenchen.de
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1612-412X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Ecology; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Bohemannia aschaueri; Bohemannia butzmanni [Russia /  / new species;
   Described from amber] [Eocene /  / ]. 
   Nepticulidae [Phylogeny / Phylogenetic tree / systematics] [Ecology /
   Paleoecology / ] [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Nepticuloidea, Nepticulidae
OR Nepticulidae (Nepticuloidea): [Fossil]. 
   Bohemannia aschaueri (Nepticulidae): [Sp nov, Russia, Eocene, P. 88,
   Described from amber; Fossil]. 
   Bohemannia butzmanni (Nepticulidae): [Sp nov, Russia, Eocene, P. 86,
   Described from amber; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR15009044226
DT Article
TI REVIEW OF ACUTIPULA CRANE FLIES OF TAIWAN, WITH DESCRIPTIONS OF NEW
   SPECIES AND IMMATURE INSTARS (DIPTERA: TIPULIDAE: TIPULINAE: TIPULA).
AU Young, Chen W. (youngc@carnegiemnh.org) 
   Li, Yan
   Chu, Wen-Chen
   Fang, Huai-Sheng
SO Annals of Carnegie Museum
VL 82
IS 2
PS 115-148
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 25
AB Taiwanese species of the crane fly subgenus Tipula (Acutipula)
   Alexander, 1924, are reviewed. Six species are recognized with two
   species being newly described: T. (A.) barbigera and T. (A.) furcifera,
   both from Nantou. Tipula (A.) shirakii Edwards, 1916, previously
   considered a synonym of T. (A.) quadrinotata Brunetti, 1912, is
   recognized as a valid taxon. The female of T. (A.) kuzuensis Alexander,
   1918, is described for the first time. DNA barcode sequences for 12
   species of T. (Acutipula) are investigated and maximum likelihood trees
   resulting from the analyses are presented. The external anatomy of the
   last instar larva and pupa of T. (A.) shirakii is described and
   illustrated. Comments concerning the biology and habitats of larvae are
   presented. A taxonomic key is provided to identify all species recorded
   in Taiwan, and their distributions are briefly discussed.
C1 Young, Chen W.; Carnegie Museum Nat Hist, Sect Invertebrate Zool, 4400
   Forbes Ave, Pittsburgh, PA, 15213, USA, USA.
EM youngc@carnegiemnh.org
SC Zoology
SN 0097-4463; 1943-6300
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Key; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Tipula (Acutipula) [Taiwan /  / Key to species] [ /  / Biology;
   distribution; systematics; review]. 
   Tipula (Acutipula) barbigera; Tipula (Acutipula) furcifera [Taiwan /  /
   New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera, Tipulidae
OR Tipula (Acutipula) - Alexander 1924 (Tipulidae): [Key to species,
   Taiwan, P. 126]. 
   Tipula (Acutipula) barbigera - Young & Li 2013 (Tipulidae): [Sp nov,
   Taiwan, P. 127]. 
   Tipula (Acutipula) furcifera - Young & Li 2013 (Tipulidae): [Sp nov,
   Taiwan, P. 128]. 
   Tipula (Acutipula) kuzuensis - Alexander 1918 (Tipulidae): [First time
   described, Female, p. 132]. 
   Tipula (Acutipula) quadrinotata - Brunetti 1912 (Tipulidae): [Removal
   from synonymy, Tipula (Acutipula) shirakii Edwards 1916, p. 138]. 
   Tipula (Acutipula) shirakii - Edwards 1916 (Tipulidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, With Tipula (Acutipula) quadrinotata Brunetti 1912, p. 138]. 
DI 10.2992/007.082.0201
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15009044226
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15009044227
DT Article
TI NEW SPECIES OF GROUND BEETLES OF THE GENUS DOLICHOCTIS SCHMIDT-GOEBEL,
   SUBGENUS SPINIDOLICHOCTIS BAEHR, FROM THE PAPUAN AND ORIENTAL REGIONS
   (INSECTA: COLEOPTERA: CARABIDAE: LEBIINAE).
AU Baehr, Martin (martin.baehr@zsm.mwn.de) 
SO Annals of Carnegie Museum
VL 82
IS 2
PS 149-163
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Eight new species of ground beetles of the lebiine genus Dolichoctis
   Schmidt-Goebel, 1846, from New Guinea and the island of Seram are
   described: D. bisetosiceps from Goodenough Island off the southeast
   coast of Papua New Guinea; D. ivimkae, D. ocularis, D. latibasis, D.
   aterrima, and D. cylindripennis from eastern and northern Papua New
   Guinea; D. lackneri from central Papua Indonesia; and D. mehli from
   Scram. All species belong to the subgenus Spinidolichoctis Baehr, 1999,
   which is characterized by the dentate or spit-lose apex of the elytra
   and the absence of the anterior marginal seta of the pronotum. This
   subgenus mainly occurs in the Papuan Region with a few species recorded
   from the southern Oriental Region and from northeastern Australia. For
   the new species, differential diagnoses are provided that distinguish
   them from related or similarly shaped species. A complete new key is
   provided for the subgenus Spinidolichoctis. Some thoughts on evolution
   and biogeography of the genus Dolichoctis in New Guinea are outlined.
C1 Baehr, Martin; Carnegie Museum Nat Hist, Sect Invertebrate Zool,
   Munchhausenstr 21, Munich, D-81247, Germany, Germany.
EM martin.baehr@zsm.mwn.de
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0097-4463; 1943-6300
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Evolution;
   Zoogeography; Land zones; Australasian region; Oriental region; Eurasia;
   Asia; Australasia
DE Dolichoctis [Evolution /  / systematics] [Zoogeography / Biogeography /
   ] [Indonesia / New Guinea / ] [Papua New Guinea /  / ]. 
   Dolichoctis (Spinidolichoctis) aterrima; Dolichoctis (Spinidolichoctis)
   bisetosiceps; Dolichoctis (Spinidolichoctis) cylindripennis; Dolichoctis
   (Spinidolichoctis) ivimkae; Dolichoctis (Spinidolichoctis) latibasis;
   Dolichoctis (Spinidolichoctis) ocularis [Papua New Guinea /  / New
   species]. 
   Dolichoctis (Spinidolichoctis) lackneri; Dolichoctis (Spinidolichoctis)
   mehli [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Dolichoctis (Carabidae). 
   Dolichoctis (Spinidolichoctis) - Baehr 1999 (Carabidae): [Key to
   species, Revised Key, p. 159]. 
   Dolichoctis (Spinidolichoctis) aterrima (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Papua New
   Guinea, P. 156]. 
   Dolichoctis (Spinidolichoctis) bisetosiceps (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Papua
   New Guinea, P. 150]. 
   Dolichoctis (Spinidolichoctis) cylindripennis (Carabidae): [Sp nov,
   Papua New Guinea, P. 156]. 
   Dolichoctis (Spinidolichoctis) ivimkae (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Papua New
   Guinea, P. 153]. 
   Dolichoctis (Spinidolichoctis) lackneri (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia,
   P. 157]. 
   Dolichoctis (Spinidolichoctis) latibasis (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Papua New
   Guinea, P. 155]. 
   Dolichoctis (Spinidolichoctis) mehli (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P.
   158]. 
   Dolichoctis (Spinidolichoctis) ocularis (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Papua New
   Guinea, P. 154].

PT J
AN ZOOR15009047860
DT Article
TI Nebria (Patrobonebria) paropamisos, a new species from the Hindu Kush
   (Coleoptera, Carabidae).
AU Huber, Charles (charles.huber@nmbe.ch) 
   Schmidt, Joachim
   Baur, Hannes
SO Contributions to Natural History (Bern)
VL 22
PS 1-14
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Nebria (Patrobonebria) paropamisos sp. nov. from the Hindu Kush
   Mountains of Afghanistan and Pakistan is decribed. Morphological and
   morphometric diagnoses to the related species N. himalayica BATES, 1889
   and N. elegans ANDREWES, 1925 and a key are given. Species separation is
   mainly based on multivariate ratio analysis (MRA), a recently developed
   method for the analysis of morphometric data.
C1 Huber, Charles; Nat Hist Museum Burgergenneinde Bern, Bernastr 15, Bern,
   CH-3005, Switzerland, Switzerland.
EM charles.huber@nmbe.ch
SC Zoology
SN 1660-9972
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   [Pakistan /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

   Carabidae

   Modified to include new species, p. 10]. 
   Nebria (Patrobonebria) paropamisos (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Pakistan, P.

PT J
AN ZOOR15009044555
DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF EUSCORPIUS FROM TINOS ISLAND, GREECE (SCORPIONES:
   EUSCORPIIDAE).
AU Fet, Victor (fet@marshall.edu) 
   Soleglad, Michael E.
   Parmakelis, Aristeidis
   Kotsakiozi, Panayiota
   Stathi, Lasmi
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 23
PS 3-10
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The scorpion genus Euscorpius has been insufficiently studied on the
   Aegean Islands of Greece. We describe a new species from the Western
   Cyclades, E. kritscheri sp. n., from Tinos Island. The species-level
   status of this form is confirmed by a phylogenetic study based on
   multiple DNA markers. In addition, a population from nearby Andros
   Island is characterized as E. cf. kritscheri, which could be potentially
   a separate species
C1 Fet, Victor; Marshall Univ, Dept Biol Sci, Huntington, WV, 25755, USA,
   USA.
EM fet@marshall.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1576-9518

DT Article
TI RAPID BIODIVERSITY ASSESSMENT, FAUNISTICS AND DESCRIPTION OF A NEW
   SPIDER SPECIES (ARANEAE) FROM DESERTAS ISLANDS AND MADEIRA (PORTUGAL).
AU Crespo, Luis Carlos (luiscarloscrespo@gmail.com) 
   Silva, Isamberto
   Borges, Paulo A.V.
   Cardoso, Pedro
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 23
PS 11-23
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The spider fauna of the Desertas Islands (Madeira) has been largely
   neglected until now, with only 11 species recorded. Both standardized
   and ad-hoc sampling was performed on organized expeditions to Desertas
   in the years 2011 and 2012. As expected for small, isolated islands,
   species richness estimates per sampled hectare are relatively low,
   ranging from 19 to 23 species. The updated local checklist now includes
   57 species, of which 11 are thought to be new for science, including a
   new species of Typhochrestus Simon, 1884, endemic to the Madeira
   archipelago, here described. The previously unknown male of Zimirina
   lepida (Blackwall, 1859) is also described. The family Ochyroceratidae
   Fage, 1912 is recorded for the first time from a native habitat in
   Europe.

TI A new species of Phrynus Lamarck, 1801 (Amblypygi: Phrynidae) from
   Guatemala and Honduras.
FT Nueva especie de Phrynus Lamarck, 1801 (Amblypygi: Phrynidae) de
   Guatemala y Honduras.
AU de Armas, Luis F. (dearmas@ecologia.cu) 
   Viquez, Carlos
   Trujillo, Rony E.
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 23
PS 25-31
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of the genus Phrynus Lamarck, 1801, based upon several
   females and males, is described from western Guatemala (Escuintla and
   Solola departments), and western Honduras.(Francisco Morazen
   department). It differs from its congeners by having a supernumerary
   spine between Pd-5 and Pd-6 (dorsal surface of the pedipalp patella).
   Also, new localities and data on natural history are given for other
   Guatemalan and Honduran whip spiders, including another case of whip
   spider predation by scorpions (previously recorded, but overlooked).

PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Intensive sampling over a period of a year has been carried out in Coves
   de Campanet, Mallorca, Balearic Islands, producing three pseudoscorpion
   species. Two of these are epigean species Chthonius (Chthonius)
   ischnocheles and Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius) tetrachelatus. The third
   is a previously undescribed species, Chthonius (Chthonius) campaneti sp.
   n., which represents the second hypogean species of the subgenus
   Chthonius known for Spain. A key for the Iberian species of the subgenus
   Chthonius is provided.

DT Article
TI The subfamily Diplocentrinae (Scorpiones: Scorpionidae) in Cuba. Part
   six: new species of Cazierius Francke 1978.
FT La subfamilia Diplocentrinae (scorpiones: Scorpionidae) en Cuba. Sexta
   parte: nueva especie de Cazierius Francke 1978.
AU Teruel, Rolando (rteruel@bioeco.ciges.inf.cu) 
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 23
PS 43-48
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Cazierius granulosus sp.n. is herein described upon a single female
   collected on the southern coast of Granma province, eastern Cuba. The
   new taxon is very easy to distinguish from all of its congeners by the
   fine and dense granulation that covers almost the entire body and
   appendages, the elongate shape of the pedipalps, and the increased
   setation of pedipalp chelae. This is the seventh Cuban representative of
   the genus, and raises the species of the subfamily and the order in the
   country to 14 and 55, respectively.

AB A new species of Ananteroides Borelli is described from the region
   located about 100 km north of Rosso, in south-western Mauritania. This
   is the second species to be described for the genus Ananteroides, which
   was created more than one century ago. The new species may represent an
   element endemic to this rather arid part of Mauritania.

DT Article
TI Rediscovery of the type of Scorpio armillatus Gervais, 1841 = Lychas
   armillatus (Gervais) (Scorpiones: Buthidae).
FT Redecouverte du type de Scorpio armillatus Gervais, 1841 = Lychas
   armillatus (Gervais) (Scorpiones: Buthidae).
AU Lourenco, Wilson R. (arachne@mnhn.fr) 
   Leguin, Elise-Anne
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 23
PS 117-118
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The type specimen of Scorpio armillatus, described by Gervais in 1841,
   has been considered lost, or at least mislaid, for a very long time.
   After several months of research in the collections of the Museum
   national d'Histoire naturelle in Paris, the female type specimen was
   rediscovered in the vial labelled RS-1498. A precise diagnosis of this
   species leads to two new conclusions: (i) S. armillatus (= Lychas
   armillatus) is not a synonym of Lychas mucronatus (Fabricius, 1798), but
   rather a valid species; (ii) Isometrus infuscatus Pocock, 1891 (= Lychas
   infuscatus), also described from the Philippines, is a junior synonym of
   L. armillatus.
C1 Lourenco, Wilson R.; Dept Systemat & Evolut, Museum Natl Hist Nat, CP
   053,57 Rue Cuvier, Paris, F-75005, France, France.
EM arachne@mnhn.fr
SC Zoology
SN 1576-9518
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Synonymy
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Scorpiones
OR Lychas armillatus - (Gervais 1841) (Scorpiones): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   117; Syn nov, Lychas infuscatus (Pocock 1891), p. 117; Removal from
   synonymy, With Lychas mucronatus (Fabricius 1798), p. 117]. 
   Lychas mucronatus - (Fabricius 1798) (Scorpiones): [Removal from
   synonymy, Lychas armillatus (Gervais 1841), p. 117]. 
   Scorpio armillatus - Gervais 1841 (Scorpiones): [Type material, Type
   specimen rediscovery, p. 117].

DT Article
TI Phrynus gervaisii (Pocock, 1894) is a junior synonym of Phrynus
   barbadensis (Pocock, 1893) (Amblypygi: Phrynidae).
AU de Armas, Luis F. (dearmas@ecologia.cu) 
   Seiter, Michael
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 23
PS 128-132
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The comparison of topotypes of Phrynus barbadensis (Pocock, 1893) with
   specimens of Phrynus gervaisii (Pocock, 1894) from Costa Rica, Colombia,
   Venezuela and Trinidad and Tobago has shown that the latter species is a
   junior synonym of the former. Also, for the first time, this species is
   recorded from Aruba (Netherland Antilles).

PM 24391827
DT Article
TI A New Species of Eagle Ray Aetobatus narutobiei from the Northwest
   Pacific: An Example of the Critical Role Taxonomy Plays in Fisheries and
   Ecological Sciences.
AU White, William T. (william.white@csiro.au) 
   Furumitsu, Keisuke
   Yamaguchi, Atsuko
SO PLoS ONE
VL 8
IS 12
PS e83785, 1-11
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 18
AB Recent taxonomic and molecular work on the eagle rays (Family
   Myliobatidae) revealed a cryptic species in the northwest Pacific. This
   species is formally described as Aetobatus narutobiei sp. nov. and
   compared to its congeners. Aetobatus narutobiei is found in eastern
   Vietnam, Hong Kong, China, Korea and southern Japan. It was previously
   considered to be conspecific with Aetobatus flagellum, but these species
   differ in size, structure of the NADH2 and CO1 genes, some morphological
   and meristic characters and colouration. Aetobatus narutobiei is
   particularly abundant in Ariake Bay in southern Japan where it is
   considered a pest species that predates heavily on farmed bivalve stocks
   and is culled annually as part of a 'predator control' program. The
   discovery of A. narutobiei highlights the paucity of detailed taxonomic
   research on this group of rays. This discovery impacts on current
   conservation assessments of A. flagellum and these need to be revised
   based on the findings of this study.
C1 White, William T.; CSIRO Marine & Atmospher Res, Wealth Oceans Flagship,
   Hobart, Tas, Australia, Australia.
EM william.white@csiro.au
RI White, William T/B-9748-2009
OI White, William T/0000-0001-9705-2453

   &Conservation

   Aetobatus narutobiei [North Pacific /  / New species] [ / China / ] [ /

DT Article
TI New contribution to the knowledge of the Iberian Meconematinae
   Burmeister, 1838 (Orthoptera: Tettigoniidae).
FT Nueva aportacion al conocimiento de los Meconematinae Burmeister, 1838
   (Orthoptera: Tettigoniidae) de la Peninsula Iberica.
AU Llucia-Pomares, David
   Quinones-Alarcon, Juan
SO Boletin de la SEA
VL 53
PS 7-30
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB We provide new information on the different taxonomic, faunistic and
   biologic characteristics of the species of Meconematinae Burmeister,
   1838 (Ensifera: Tettigoniidae) present in the Iberian Peninsula.
   Meconema meridionale Costa, 1860 is recorded for the first time from the
   Iberian Peninsula and Spain; the male Cyrtaspis tuberculata Barranco,
   2005, unknown until now, is described thanks to the discovery of a new
   population of the species in Malaga province; a new Canariola emarginata
   Newman, 1964 subspecies native to the Tejeda mountains (Granada) is
   described; the taxonomic identity of the Iberian populations identified
   as Cyrtaspis scutata (Charpentier, 1825) is discussed based on the
   preliminary taxonomic study of a new Andalusian population similar to
   this species; finally, we include an identification key for the group of
   Iberian species, illustrating for the first time the different
   morphological structures of the abdominal terminalia of each of them
   with photographic records of fresh specimens.

PT J
AN ZOOR15202008392
DT Article
TI Cladistic analysis of the Iberian genera of the tribe Pedinini
   (Coleoptera, Tenebrionidae) with description of a new genus and comments
   about the genus Psammoardoinellus Leo, 1981.
FT Analisis cladistico de la tribu Pedinini (Coleoptera, Tenebrionidae) de
   la peninsula iberica, descripcion de un nuevo genero y comentarios sobre
   el genero Psammoardoinellus Leo, 1981.
AU Ferrer, Julio
SO Boletin de la SEA
VL 53
PS 31-55
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB To establish the position of the genus Phylan Dejean, 1821 and trace the
   possible phylogeny of the tribe Pedinini Eschscholtz (1849) 28 taxa were
   studied and a matrix of 99 morphological external and genital characters
   was used. A parsimony analysis was run in Nona (Goloboff, 1999) with the
   heuristic search options hold 10000, Mult*100, hold/10, mult*max*
   spawned from Winclada (Nixon, 1999-2002). Glade support values were
   calculated with a bootstrap analysis with 500 replications and the
   heuristic search settings Mult*5, hold/2 and no max* TBR. The parsimony
   analysis found two most parsimonious trees with length 360, Cl 0.26 and
   RI 0.43. Twelve nodes collapsed in the strict consensus of the two
   topologies. The dilemma cannot be resolved before a revision of the
   tribe, but is irrelevant for the treatment of Phylan presented in this
   paper. As a result of the analysis all subgenera belonging to the
   "Phylan" conglomerate sensu Vinolas & Cartagena (2003) are elevated to
   generic level. Moreover, Phylanmania gen. nov. is described to
   accommodate two species, Heliopates escalerai Espanol, 1943 and Phylan
   ilerdensis Espanol & Vinolas, 1981, and the following new combinations
   are proposed: Phylanmania escalerai (Espanol, 1943) comb. nov. and
   Phylanmania ilerdensis (Espanol & Vinolas, 1981) comb. nov.; Heliopathes
   (Olocrates) mulsanti and Heliopathes (Olocrates) reyi, described by
   Piochard de la Brulerie, 1869 and included in Litoboriolus by Espanol
   (1945), are retransferred to the genus Phylan Dejean, 1821, following
   the opinion of Gebien (1938). The uncertain placement of the genus
   Psammoardoinellus Leo, 1981 in the tribe Melambiina is discussed.
C1 Ferrer, Julio; Swedish Museum Nat Hist, Dept Entomol, Estocolmo,
   S-10504, Sweden, Sweden.
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1134-6094
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Status; General morphology; Evolution;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Pedinini [General morphology /  / systematics] [Phylogeny / Cladistics /
   ] [Europe / Iberian Peninsula / biology; distribution] [Spain /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

   Tenebrionidae

   (Dendarophylan), p. 39]. 
   Heliophilus escalerai - Espanol 1943 (Tenebrionidae): [Referred to, New
   genus Phylanmania, p. 38].

   (Litoboriolus), p. 38].

   (Litororus), p. 41]. 
   Pedinini (Tenebrionidae). 
   Phylan - Dejean 1821 (Tenebrionidae): [Revision, P. 31]. 
   Phylan (Dendarophylan) - Espanol 1947 (Tenebrionidae): [Raised to,
   Dendarophylan, p. 39]. 
   Phylan (Litoboriolus) - Espanol 1945 (Tenebrionidae): [Raised to,
   Litoboriolus, p. 38].

   Litororus, p. 41]. 
   Phylan ilerdensis - Espanol & Vinolas 1981 (Tenebrionidae): [Designated
   type species for new genus, Phylanmania, p. 38]. 
   Phylan mulsanti - Piochard 1869 (Tenebrionidae): [Taxonomic position, P.
   38]. 
   Phylan reyi - Piochard 1869 (Tenebrionidae): [Taxonomic position, P.
   38]. 
   Phylanmania (Tenebrionidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Pedini, Type species
   Phylan ilerdensis Espanol & Vinolas 1981, p. 38]. 
   Phylanmania escalerai - (Espanol 1943) (Tenebrionidae): [Comb nov,

VL 53
PS 57-62
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Bruchidius gavirai, a new species of seed beetle (Coleoptera: Bruchidae)
   from the south of the Iberian Peninsula, is described. This species
   feeds on the seeds of Cistaceae and is very similar to Bruchidius cisti
   (Fabricius, 1775), especially when it comes to the male genitalia. Some
   characters are proposed to separate these two species linked to
   Cistaceae family.

AB the South American Chnoodini genera are reviewed and keyed. The new
   genera Gordonita and Incurvus are described, and the new species
   Gordonita anomala, Incurvus mimus, Chnoodes bipartitus, C. maculamantis,

   material collected in the town of Lucena (Cordoba, Spain) and
   surroundings. The new species is very close to Vesperus fuentei Pic,

AB Iberodorcadion (Hispanodorcadion) bolivari danielae ssp. n. is described
   based on specimens captured in Aranjuez (Madrid); its biology is studied
   and an analysis is made of the morphological differences separating it
   from the two nearest taxa, Iberodorcadion (Hispanodorcadion) bolivari s.
   str. (Lauffer, 1898) and Iberodorcadion (Hispanodorcadion) martinezii
   (Perez Arcas, 1874), providing new data on the geographical distribution
   of these two species.

PT J
AN ZOOR15202008401
DT Article
TI Contributions to the knowledge of the subgenus Alphasida Escalera.
   Alphasida solieri fuscopepla Koch, 1940, species composita (Coleoptera:
   Tenebrionidae).
FT Aportaciones al estudio del subgenero Alphasida Escalera. Alphasida
   solieri fuscopepla Koch, 1940, species composita (Coleoptera:
   Tenebrionidae).
AU Ferrer, Julio
SO Boletin de la SEA
VL 53
PS 135-141
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB The type series of Alphasida solieri fuscopepla Koch, 1940, collected in
   Loja (Granada, Spain), has proved to include two species: Alphasida
   fuscopepla Koch, 1940, stat. nov. and Alphasida clementei (Perez Arcas,
   1865). The first species is redescribed and elevated to specfic rank as
   a result of a comparison with the second, which has brought to light
   significative differences in habitus and genital organs. The combination
   Alphasida fuscopepla Koch, 1940, stat. nov. is proposed, and Its habitus
   and genitalia are illustrated for the first time. A. fuscopepla Koch, is
   compared with Alphasida subbaetica Obregon and Verdugo, 2012, described
   from the nearby locality of Carcabuey, Cordoba province. The name
   Alphasida clementei (Perez Arcas, 1865) has priority over Alphasida
   solieri (Rambur, 1839) nom. preocc., a binomen already used for a
   species from Sardinia by Gene (1836). Alphasida clementei (Perez Arcas)
   is recorded for the first time from Malaga.
C1 Ferrer, Julio; Swedish Museum Nat Hist, Dept Entomol, Stockholm,
   S-10405, Sweden, Sweden.
SC Zoology
SN 1134-6094
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Taxonomy; Status; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Alphasida (Alphasida) [Spain /  / Biology; distribution; new record;
   systematics]. 
   Alphasida clementei [Spain / Malaga / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

   Tenebrionidae

   Alphasida solieri fuscopepla, p. 136].

PT J

PM 24391859
DT Article
TI Comparative Mitogenomic Analysis Reveals Sexual Dimorphism in a Rare
   Montane Lacewing (Insecta: Neuroptera: Ithonidae).
AU Wang, Yuyu
   Liu, Xingyue (xingyue_liu@yahoo.com) 
   Winterton, Shaun L.
   Yan, Yan
   Chang, Wencheng
   Yang, Ding
SO PLoS ONE
VL 8
IS 12
PS e83986, 1-13
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Rapisma McLachlan, 1866 (Neuroptera: Ithonidae) is a rarely encountered
   genus of lacewings found inmontane tropical or subtropical forests in
   Oriental Asia. In Xizang Autonomous Region (Tibet) of China there are
   two sympatrically distributed species of Rapisma, i.e. Rapisma
   xizangense Yang, 1993 and Rapisma zayuanum Yang, 1993, in which R.
   xizangense is only known as male and has dull brownish body and wing
   coloration, while R. zayuanum is only known as female and has bright
   green body and wing coloration. In order to clarify the relationship
   between these two species, we determined the complete mitochondrial (mt)
   genomes of R. xizangense and R. zayuanum for the first time. The mt
   genomes are 15,961 and 15,984 bp in size, respectively, and comprised 37
   genes (13 protein coding genes, 22 tRNA genes and 2 rRNA genes). A major
   noncoding (control) region was 1,167 bp in R. xizangense and 1,193 bp in
   R. zayuanum with structural organizations simpler than that reported in
   other Neuropterida species, notably lacking conserved blocks or long
   tandem repeats. Besides similar mitogenomic structure, the genetic
   distance between R. xizangense and R. zayuanum based on two rRNAs and 13
   protein coding genes (PCGs) as well as the genetic distance between each
   of these two Tibetan Rapisma species and a Thai Rapisma species (R.
   cryptunum) based on partial rrnL show that R. xizangense and R. zayuanum
   are most likely conspecific. Thus, R. zayuanum syn. nov. is herein
   treated as a junior synonym of R. xizangense. The present finding
   represents a rare example of distinct sexual dimorphism in lacewings.
   This comparative mitogenomic analysis sheds new light on the
   identification of rare species with sexual dimorphism and the biology of
   Neuroptera.
C1 Liu, Xingyue; China Agr Univ, Dept Entomol, Beijing, 100094, China,
   China.
EM xingyue_liu@yahoo.com
RI Liu, Xingyue/A-3019-2013; Winterton, Shaun L/C-3804-2009; Wang,
   Yuyu/J-3117-2019
OI Liu, Xingyue/0000-0002-9168-0659; Yan, Yan/0000-0002-4994-2651
SC Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Genetics &Heredity
SN 1932-6203
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Colour and luminescence;
   Reproduction; Genetics; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia;
   China
DE Rapisma xizangense; Rapisma zayuanum [Colour /  / taxonomic
   implications] [Sex differences / Sexual dimorphism / ] [Molecular
   genetics / Complete mitochondrial genome / ] [Xizang / Zayu County,
   Shaqiong Village / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR15011060195
DT Article
TI Na Duong (northern Vietnam) - an exceptional window into Eocene
   ecosystems from Southeast Asia.
AU Boehme, Madelaine (m.boehme@ifg.uni-tuebingen.de) 
   Aiglstorfer, Manuela
   Antoine, Pierre-Olivier
   Appel, Erwin
   Havlik, Philipe
   Metais, Gregoire
   Laq The Phuc
   Schneider, Simon
   Setzer, Fabian
   Tappert, Ralf
   Dang Ngoc Tran
   Uhi, Dieter
   Prieto, Jerome
SO Zitteliana Reihe A Mitteilungen der Bayerischen Staatssammlung fuer
   Palaeontologie und Geologie
VL 53
PS 121-167
PD Dec 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Today, the continental ecosystems of Southeast Asia represent a global
   biodiversity hotspot. From a deep-time perspective, however, very little
   is known about the formation of this hotspot. In particular, the
   evolutionary and biogeographic roots of numerous terrestrial biota are
   unknown, and ecosystemic information, especially for the Paleogene, is
   unavailable. The Na Duong Basin in northern Vietnam has yielded a
   remarkable diversity of Paleogene vertebrate, invertebrate, and plant
   fossils, and is thus one of the few localities in Southeast Asia
   allowing for multi-focused investigation of this period. We present
   stratigraphic, paleontologic, and paleoecologic results from the 220 m
   thick Na Duong section derived from magnetostratigraphy, biochronology,
   vertebrate, invertebrate, and plant taxonomy, and biomarker analysis.
   Only the upper 40 m of the section show the original magnetization,
   prohibiting any further magnetostratigraphic interpretation. The
   affinities of two newly described mammal species, Bakalovia orientalis
   nov. sp. (Anthracotheriidae) and Epiaceratherium naduongense nov. sp.
   (Rhinocerotidae), suggest an Eocene, late Bartonian to Priabonian age
   (39-35 Ma). High biodiversity is recorded for unionid mussels (five
   species), freshwater fishes (nine taxa, including Planktophaga minuta
   nov. gen. et sp.), turtles (five to six taxa), and crocodiles (three
   taxa), and long-term stability of Southeast Asian unionid and fish
   faunas is demonstrated. Fossil leaves, wood and resin document azonal
   and zonal vegetation; dipterocarp trees were identified from resin
   exudate spectroscopy. In-situ tree-stump horizons allow for calculation
   of tree density (600 specimens/ha) and maximum canopy height (35m); both
   values resemble those of recent Southeast Asian peat swamp forests.
   Environment changed abruptly from a swamp forest to a tropical to warm
   sub-tropical lake of fluctuating water depth. The strong biogeographic
   link between the Eocene mammal faunas from Na Duong and Europe
   highlights the importance of Southeast Asia as a source region for
   trans-continental mammal dispersal along the northern Tethys margin.
C1 Boehme, Madelaine; Univ Tubingen, Dept Geosci, Sigwartstr 10, Tubingen,
   D-72076, Germany, Germany.
EM m.boehme@ifg.uni-tuebingen.de
OI Schneider, Simon/0000-0001-6493-357X
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Paleontology
SN 1612-412X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Zoogeography; Land zones;
   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Bakalovia orientalis; Epiaceratherium naduongense; Planktophaga minuta
   [Vietnam /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
   Planktophaga [Eocene /  / New genus]. 
   Vertebrata [Ecology / Palaeoecology / ] [Fossil assemblages /  / ]
   [Dispersal /  / ] [Vietnam / Na Duong / stratigraphical distribution]
   [Eocene / Late Bartonian - Priabonian / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Mammals; Ungulates; Vertebrates

   Actinopterygii, Cypriniformes, Cyprinidae
OR Vertebrata (Chordata): [Fossil].

   P. 140; Fossil].

   p. 146, Eocene; Fossil].

PT J

DT Article
TI Biodiversity and Evolutionary History of [dagger]Lophionotus
   (Neopterygii: [dagger]Semionotiformes) from the Western United States.
AU Gibson, Sarah Z. (szgibson@ku.edu) 
SO Copeia
VL 4
PS 582-603
PD Dec 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two species of the neopterygian genus [dagger]Lophionotus Gibson, 2013,
   are described. Specimens of [dagger]Lophionotus chinleana, new species,
   were previously and recently collected from freshwater deposits in the
   Upper Triassic Chinle Formation of Lisbon Valley, southeastern Utah.
   [dagger]Semionotus kanabensis Schaeffer and Dunkle, 1950, from
   lacustrine deposits in the Lower Jurassic Moenave Formation of
   southwestern Utah, is herein redescribed and attributed to the genus
   [dagger]Lophionotus, based on shared characters, including the
   infraorbital in the posteroventral corner of the orbit being expanded
   and contacting the anterior ramus of the preoperculum. Both new species
   of [dagger]Lophionotus are distinct from [dagger]L. sanjuanensis Gibson,
   2013, in that they lack a postcranial hump, deep body, dense
   tuberculation, and ventrally expanded preoperculum. The addition of two
   new species lends to a revised generic description of the genus
   [dagger]Lophionotus. A phylogenetic analysis infers a monophyletic
   [dagger]Lophionotus sister to the genus [dagger]Semionotus, and
   [dagger]Lophionotus is placed within the family [dagger]Semionotidae
   within [dagger]Semionotiformes.
C1 Gibson, Sarah Z.; Univ Kansas, Dept Geol, 1345 Jayhawk Blvd, Lawrence,
   KS, 66045, USA, USA.
EM szgibson@ku.edu

   Nearctic region; North America; USA; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Ginglymodi; Lophionotus [Phylogeny /  / Taxonomic implications].

DT Article
TI A New Hyphessobrycon Durbin from the Rio Teles Pires, Rio Tapajos Basin,
   Mato Grosso State, Brazil (Characiformes: Characidae).
AU Teixeira, Tulio F. (fratute@hotmail.com) 
   Lima, Flavio C.T.
   Zuanon, Jansen
SO Copeia
VL 4
PS 612-621
PD Dec 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of Hyphessobrycon Durbin is described from the Rio Teles
   Pires, Rio Tapajos basin, Mato Grosso State, Brazil. The new species can
   be distinguished from all congeners, except for Hyphessobrycon
   bifasciatus, H. cyanotaenia, H. heliacus, H. igneus, H. loweae, and H.
   peugeoti by having the distal border of the anal fin slightly convex to
   straight in adult males, without a distinct anterior lobe, and with last
   unbranched ray and first to second branched ray shorter than the
   subsequent branched rays. The new species can be distinguished from H.
   bifasciatus, H. cyanotaenia, H. heliacus, H. igneus, H. loweae, and H.
   peugeoti by the presence of octa- to decacuspid teeth on both dentary
   and inner premaxillary series (vs. tri- to heptacuspid dentary and
   premaxillary teeth) and dark chromatophores concentrated on the
   posterior border of the body scales, forming a reticulated pattern (vs.
   reticulated pattern absent).
C1 Teixeira, Tulio F.; Univ Sao Paulo, Museu Zool, Ave Nazare 481, Sao
   Paulo, BR-04263000 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM fratute@hotmail.com

SN 0045-8511

DT Article
TI A New Species of Listrura from Laguna dos Patos System, Brazil: The
   Southernmost Record of the Glanapteryginae (Siluriformes:
   Trichomycteridae).
AU Villa-Verde, Leandro (lvvsilva@gmail.com) 
   Ferrer, Juliano
   Malabarba, Luiz R.
SO Copeia
VL 4
PS 641-646
PD Dec 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Listrura depinnai, new species, is described from a small swampy area
   belonging to Laguna dos Patos system, Municipality of Viamao, Rio Grande
   do Sul state, southern Brazil. It occurs within the wildlife reserve
   Refugio de Vida Silvestre Banhado dos Pachecos, and represents the
   southernmost record of the glanapterygine catfishes. The new species is
   easily distinguished from remaining Listrura by having the following
   putative autapomorphies: the region below the midline of flank covered
   by several spots (vs. unpigmented or with a slender row of small spots);
   the caudal peduncle at procurrent-ray folds deeper than the preanal
   portion of body (vs. approximately the same depth); and the presence of
   a conspicuous intumescence adjacent to the posterodorsal margin of the
   pectoral-fin base (vs. swelling slight or absent). Putative phylogenetic
   positions of Listrura depinnai are herein discussed.
C1 Villa-Verde, Leandro; Univ Fed Rio de Janeiro, Dept Vertebrados, Rio De
   Janeiro, RJ, BR-20940040 BC, Brazil, Brazil.

DT Article
TI Taxonomy and phylogeny of western Atlantic Lucinidae: new genus for
   Lucina costata d'Orbigny, 1846, a new species of Ferrocina and neotype
   designation for Venus orbiculata (Montagu, 1808).
AU Taylor, John D. (j.taylor@nhm.ac.uk) 
   Glover, Emily A.
   Williams, Suzanne T.
SO Nautilus
VL 127
IS 4
PS 131-146
PD Dec 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 16
AB A new genus, Clathrolucina Taylor and Glover, is proposed for the widely
   distributed western Atlantic species Lucina costata d'Orbigny, 1846,
   which has previously been placed in Codakia, Ctena, and Parvilucina.
   Molecular evidence indicates a closer relationship to Radiolucina and
   Lucinisca. A new species, Ferrocina garciai Taylor and Glover, is
   described from submerged pinnacles off the coasts of Louisiana and
   Alabama. It is similar to Ferrocina species described from the western
   Pacific and, in molecular analysis clusters, with Parvilucina and
   Bathyaustriella. Unusual features of this species include the large
   ctenidia and the lateral coiled pouches of the visceral mass. A neotype
   is designated for Lucina orbiculata Montagu, 1808 aka Ctena orbiculata,
   an abundant shallow water lucinid of the western Atlantic. The original
   type material is missing, the type locality is erroneous and
   considerable doubt exists about the identity of this species.
C1 Taylor, John D.; Nat Hist Museum, Dept Life Sci, Cromwell Rd, London,
   SW7 5BD, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM j.taylor@nhm.ac.uk
RI Williams, Suzanne/A-9604-2008
OI Williams, Suzanne/0000-0003-2995-5823

   Lucinidae [Phylogeny /  / Systematics] [Atlantic Ocean / West / ].

DT Article
TI Extractrix dockeryi, a new species from the Eocene of the southeastern
   United States, with notes on open coiling in the Cancellariidae
   (Gastropoda: Neogastropoda).
AU Harasewych, M.G. (Harasewych@si.edu) 
   Petit, Richard E.
SO Nautilus
VL 127
IS 4
PS 147-152
PD Dec 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Extractrix dockeryi is described from beds of Middle Eocene (Bartonian)
   age in the Gosport Sand Formation at Little Stave Creek, Alabama and the
   contemporaneous McBean Formation at Orangeburg, South Carolina. This new
   species represents the earliest occurrence of open coiling in the family
   Cancellariidae. Other records of open coiling in the Cancellariidae are
   reviewed, and the taxonomic status and composition of the genus
   Extractrix is discussed.

DT Article
TI A New Species of Anagrus (Hymenoptera: Mymaridae) from Tahiti, with
   Notes on Egg Parasitoids of Proconiine Sharpshooters (Hemiptera:
   Cicadellidae: Proconiini) in the World.
AU Triapitsyn, Serguei V. (serguei.triapitsyn@ucr.edu) 
SO Journal of Taiwan Agricultural Research
VL 62
IS 4
PS 289-299
PD Dec 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB One new fairyfly (Hymenoptera: Mymaridae) species, Anagrus (Anagrus) iti
   sp. n., described from Tahiti Island, French Polynesia, was reared from
   eggs of the invasive glassy-winged sharpshooter, Homalodisca varipennis
   (Germar) (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae), which is native to southeastern USA
   and northeastern Mexico. An overview of the taxonomic and biological
   studies on the egg parasitoids (Hymenoptera: Aphelinidae, Mymaridae, and
   Trichogrammatidae) of various proconiine sharpshooters (Cicadellidae:
   Cicadellinae: Proconiini) in the New World is given. Of particular
   importance are the natural enemies of H. varipennis, a notorious vector
   of the phytopathogenic bacterium, Xylella fastidiosa; with reference to
   its egg parasitoids and biological control in the non-native range are
   also provided.

DT Article
TI New Species of Doumea (Siluriformes: Amphiliidae) from Coastal River
   Basins of the Republic of the Congo.
AU Ferraris, Carl J., Jr
   Vari, Richard P. (carlferraris@comcast.net) 
SO Copeia
VL 4
PS 577-581
PD Dec 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB new species of the African catfish subfamily Doumeinae of the family
   Amphiliidae is described from collections made in the Dimonika Biosphere
   Reserve in the eastern portion of the Republic of the Congo. The
   species, assignable to the genus Doumea, has the smallest known maximum
   length of the nine species of that genus. The new species is readily
   distinguishable from its congeners in having a relatively low number of
   pectoral-fin rays, vertebrae, and ribs and several morphometric
   features, especially those involving the caudal peduncle.
C1 Vari, Richard P.; Smithsonian Inst, Natl Museum Nat Hist, POB
   37012,WG-14,MRC 159, Washington, DC, 20013, USA, USA.
EM carlferraris@comcast.net
SC Zoology
SN 0045-8511
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Africa
DE Doumea skeltoni [Congo-Brazzaville /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Siluriformes, Amphiliidae

PT J
AN ZOOR15010052009
DT Article
TI Revision of the Neotropical Genus Acrobrycon (Ostariophysi:
   Characiformes: Characidae) with Description of Two New Species.
AU Arcila, Dahiana
   Vari, Richard P. (arciladk@gmail.com) 
   Menezes, Naercio A.
SO Copeia
VL 4
PS 604-611
PD Dec 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Acrobrycon, a genus of Neotropical freshwater fishes from the western
   Amazon and northwestern portions of the La Plata basin is revised. The
   genus is found to include three species, two of which are new to
   science. Acrobrycon ipanquianus is distributed from the western portions
   of the Rio Amazonas through to the northwestern region of the Rio de La
   Plata basin; A. starnesi, new species, in the southwestern portion of
   the Amazon basin in Bolivia; and A. ortii, new species, in the
   northwestern Rio de La Plata basin in Argentina. Members of the genus
   are distinguished from each other on the basis of the depth at the
   dorsal-fin origin, the horizontal eye diameter, the least interorbital
   width, and the numbers of perforated lateral-line scales, anal-fin rays,
   and horizontal scales around the caudal peduncle. The analysis found
   that A. tarijae, described from the Rio Lipeo in Bolivia, cannot be
   distinguished morphologically from A. ipanquianus; thus, A. tarijae is
   placed into the synonymy of A. ipanquianus.
C1 Vari, Richard P.; Smithsonian Inst, Natl Museum Nat Hist, POB
   37012,WG-14,MRC 159, Washington, DC, 20013, USA, USA.
EM arciladk@gmail.com
RI Menezes, Naercio A./K-8763-2013
SC Zoology
SN 0045-8511
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Acrobrycon [South America / Central / Distribution; taxonomic revision].
   
   Acrobrycon ortii [Argentina /  / New species]. 
   Acrobrycon starnesi [Bolivia /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,

   tarijae Fowler 1940, p. 605]. 
   Acrobrycon ortii (Characidae): [Sp nov, Argentina, P. 609]. 
   Acrobrycon starnesi (Characidae): [Sp nov, Bolivia, P. 607].

AN ZOOR15010052012
DT Article
TI Description of a New Small Species of the Genus Cyphocharax
   (Characiformes: Curimatidae) from the Lower Amazon Basin.
AU Wosiacki, Wolmar Benjamin (wolmar@museu-goeldi.br) 
   da Silva Miranda, Dylria Paula
SO Copeia
VL 4
PS 627-633
PD Dec 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Cyphocharax aninha, new species, is described from the Rio Mopeco, a
   left tributary of the Rio Paru, left of the lower Rio Amazonas.
   Cyphocharax aninha differs from its congeners by having the infraorbital
   sensory canal absent or greatly reduced, even in large individuals (more
   than 30.0 mm SL), and fleshy or osseous canal restricted to infraorbital
   5; the presence of a broad ellipsoid, vertical elongate spot over the
   caudal peduncle and the base of the caudal-fin rays, between the dorsal
   and ventral margins of the caudal peduncle. The new species can also be
   distinguished from all congeners by the combination of morphometric,
   meristic, and pigmentation characters. Comments on other small species
   and possible relationships of the new species with its congeners are
   presented.
C1 Wosiacki, Wolmar Benjamin; Museu Paraense Emilio Goeldi, Setor Ictiol,
   Caixa Postal 399, Belem, Para, BR-66040170 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM wolmar@museu-goeldi.br

SN 0045-8511

AN ZOOR15010052013
DT Article
TI A Second Species of Trachycephalus Tschudi (Anura: Hylidae) with a
   Single Vocal Sac from the Brazilian Amazon.
AU Nunes, Ivan (ivan.nunes@yahoo.com.br) 
   Suarez, Pablo
   Gordo, Marcelo
   Pombal, Jose P., Jr
SO Copeia
VL 4
PS 634-640
PD Dec 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species of Trachycephalus from the Brazilian Amazon Rain Forest,
   morphologically similar to T. hadroceps (Duellman and Hoogmoed), is
   described. This new species is characterized by having the skin not
   co-ossified with the skull; skin on dorsum bearing many low and medium
   round tubercles; a vocal sac not externally visible; well-developed
   paratoid gland; snout rounded in profile; third finger disc almost the
   same size of the eye; absence of tarsal fold; iris pinkish-beige with a
   horizontal dark gray bar; dorsal color pattern in life light
   brownish-orange with scattered brown dots. Trachycephalus hadroceps is
   restricted to the left margin (north) of the Amazon River, in the Guiana
   Shield, and possibly in the adjacent Brazilian Amazon Rain Forest, and
   the new species occurs on the right margin (south) of the Amazon River.
   It is a canopy treefrog, which probably uses treeholes filled with water
   as breeding sites.
C1 Nunes, Ivan; Univ Fed Rio de Janeiro, Dept Vertebrados, Rio De Janeiro,
   RJ, BR-20940040 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM ivan.nunes@yahoo.com.br

   Silva/E-5309-2013; Pombal, Jose/C-6365-2015

   Nunes Silva/0000-0001-7985-2836; Pombal, Jose/0000-0003-4900-630X

PT J
AN ZOOR15010052029
DT Article
TI Ontogenetic and Comparative Morphology of Clinch Dace (Chrosomus sp cf.
   saylori).
AU White, Shannon L. (swhite8@vt.edu) 
   Orth, Donald J.
SO Copeia
VL 4
PS 750-756
PD Dec 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Clinch Dace (Chrosomus sp. cf. saylori) is a rare species of minnow with
   fragmented populations occurring in the upper Clinch River watershed in
   Virginia. Major morphological and life history characteristics have not
   been described for Clinch Dace, and evidence that Clinch Dace is a new
   species is largely anecdotal. Here, we compare Clinch Dace morphometric
   and meristic characteristics to those of closely related congeners and
   test for sexual and ontogenetic changes in morphology. We also
   determined diet preference through gut content analysis. We conclude
   that Clinch Dace are morphologically distinct from congeners, and that
   there are changes in morphology attributable to sex and ontogenetic
   development. This study suggests that Clinch Dace is a distinct species,
   and isolation of Clinch Dace from congeners has led to distinct,
   measurable differences in morphology. Furthermore, digestive anatomy of
   Clinch Dace combined with a diet high in macroinvertebrates suggests
   that Clinch Dace occupy a trophic niche that is atypical for Chrosomus.
C1 White, Shannon L.; Virginia Tech, Dept Fish & Wildlife Conservat, 100
   Cheatham Hall, Blacksburg, VA, 24061, USA, USA.
EM swhite8@vt.edu
RI Orth, Donald J/X-8620-2018; ANIKUZHIYIL, ANISH/Y-8609-2018
OI Orth, Donald J/0000-0002-9236-0147; ANIKUZHIYIL,
   ANISH/0000-0001-9686-1283
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Developmental
   Biology
SN 0045-8511
BD Biometrics; General morphology; Reproduction; Life cycle and development
DE Chrosomus saylori [Biometrics / Morphometrics / ] [General morphology /
   Internal & external morphology / ] [Sex differences / Sexual dimorphism
   / ] [Development / Ontogeny / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cypriniformes, Cyprinidae

TI On the status of Dienerella vincenti JOHNSON, 2007 and Dienerella
   elongata (CURTIS, 1830) (Coleoptera, Latridiidae).
AU Reike, Hans-Peter (latridiidae@gmx.de) 
SO Latridiidae
VL 10
PS 5-8
PD Dec 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The name Dienerella elongata (CURTIS, 1830) is valid. CURTIS, 1830, gave
   a careful description and excellent drawings. The identity is supported
   by data on the original distribution of the species. Dienerella vincenti
   JOHNSON, 2007 is a junior synonym.

DT Article; Meeting paper
TI A new species of Atractomerus Duponchel y Chevrolat (Coleoptera:
   Curculionidae: Anthonomini) from the El Cielo Biosphere Reserve in
   northeastern Mexico.
AU Jones, Robert W. (rjones@uaq.mx) 
   Nino Maldonado, Santiago
SO Dugesiana
VL 20
IS 2
PS 141-143
PD Dec 28 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species, Atractomerus tlatoani n. sp. (Coleoptera: Curculionidae:
   Anthonomini), is described from a series of specimens collected from the
   El Cielo Biosphere Reserve of northeastern Mexico. Characters that
   separate the species from members of the rest of the genus are: 1) the
   profemoral tooth large, simple and the anterior margin straight without
   a basal prominence; 2) elytral interstria 3 not prominent at the extreme
   base; 3) well-developed subbasal prominence on interstria 4 equal to or
   greater in elevation than anteromedian elevation on interstria 2; 4)
   basal patch of dark fuscous elytral scales that extends across
   interstria 2 and 3 and reaches subbasal prominence on interstria 4; and
   5) penis in dorsal view laceolate in shape and apex without lateral
   apicoventral prominences.
C1 Jones, Robert W.; Univ Autonoma Queretaro, Fac Ciencias Nat, Ave
   Ciencias S-N, Juriquilla, Queretaro, 76230, Mexico, Mexico.
EM rjones@uaq.mx

SN 1028-3420

   region; North America

TI Paracratomorphus new genus (Coleoptera: Lampyridae: Cratomorphini) of

PD Dec 28 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Paracratomorphus new genus, reyesi sp. nov. is described from Chipinque,
   Monterrey, Nuevo Leon, Mexico. It is compared with Cratomorphus and
   Diaphanes, which present similarities in the pronotum and male
   genitalia. Is is segregated from them by differences in the eyes and
   antennae.

TI A new species of Euplocania Enderlein (Psocodea: 'Psocoptera':
   Ptiloneuridae), from Magdalena, Colombia, with a proposed classification
   of the genus.
AU Garcia Aldrete, Alfonso N. (anga@ib.unam.mx) 
   Gonzalez Obando, Ranulfo
   Carrejo, Nancy S.
SO Dugesiana
VL 20
IS 2
PS 149-156
PD Dec 28 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A species of Euplocania from the National Natural Park Tayrona,
   Magdalena, Colombia, is here described and illustrated, it is assigned
   to the Zelayensis species group. On the basis of forewing pigmentation,
   shape of the pterostigma, and structure of the hypandrium, eight species
   groups are recognized in Euplocania, which are here diagnosed, with
   species assigned to each and distribution. The genus presently includes
   38 species, only nine of which have been described.

DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Review of Andricus species (Hymenoptera, Cynipidae) producing woody
   tuberous oak galls in Mexico and bordering areas of United States of
   America.
AU Pujade-Villar, J. (jpujade@ub.edu) 
   Perez-Garcia, A.G.
   Equihua-Martinez, A.
   Estrada-Venegas, E.G.
   Cibrian-Tovar, D.
   Barrera-Ruiz, U.M.
   Ferrer-Suay, M.
SO Dugesiana
VL 20
IS 2
PS 183-208
PD Dec 28 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A revision of tuberous oak galls induced by Andricus species from Mexico
   is given. Andricus guanajuatensis Pujade-Villar n. sp., A. santafe
   Pujade-Villar n. sp. and A. carrilloi Pujade-Villar n. sp. (Hymenoptera:
   Cynipidae: Cynipini) are described from Mexico. Diagnosis, biology and
   distribution data of all Andricus species are given. Some morphological
   characters are discussed, illustrated and compared between related
   species. A key for all Mexican species and two North American species
   collected next to Mexico (Andricus wheeleri and A. lebaue Pujade-Villar
   n. sp.) is included. The gall and host of Andricus dugesi Beutenmuller
   is described for the first time.

TI Three new Mexican species of Phyllophaga Harris (Coleoptera:
   Melolonthidae: Melolonthinae).

AB Three new species of Phyllophaga (s.str.) are described: P. vallendensis
   n. sp. collected in oak and pine forests located in Villa de Allende and
   Temascaltepec, State of Mexico and Taxco, Guerrero; P. reyescastilloi n.
   sp. obtained in oak and pine forest near Taxco, Guerrero; and P. gloriae
   n. sp., collected in mountain forests of Tapalpa, Manantlan and Arroyo
   Colorado, Jalisco, Mexico. Figures of diagnostic characters, dorsal and
   lateral habitus, and comments about differences of the new species with
   other Mexican species of Phyllophaga are included.

DT Article
TI Systematic revision of the Potamotrygon motoro (Muller & Henle, 1841)
   species complex in the Parana-Paraguay basin, with description of two
   new ocellated species (Chondrichthyes: Myliobatiformes:
   Potamotrygonidae).
AU Loboda, Thiago Silva (loboda_bio@yahoo.com.br) 
   de Carvalho, Marcelo Rodrigues
SO Neotropical Ichthyology
VL 11
IS 4
PS 693-737
PD Dec 27 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 17
AB A systematic revision of the Potamotrygon motoro (Muller & Henle, 1841)
   species complex in the Parana-Paraguay basin based on morphological
   characters was undertaken. Morphological systems analyzed include
   external morphology, coloration, dermal denticles, and spines, canals of
   the ventral lateral-line system, and skeletal components. Potamotrygon
   motoro is widely distributed in the Parana-Paraguay basin and some of
   its diagnostic characters are: ocelli present on dorsal disc tricolored,
   well-defined and evenly distributed, with diameter similar or greater
   than eye-length; ventral coloration with relatively large whitish
   central region, with gray or brown area predominant on outer ventral
   disc margins; dermal denticles well-developed and star-shaped over
   central disc; labial grooves absent; monognathic heterodonty present in
   upper and lower jaws of adults. Potamotrygon pauckei Castex, 1963 and
   Potamotrygon labradori Castex, Maciel & Achenbach, 1963, are synonymized
   with P. motoro; Potamotrygon alba Castex, 1963, is a nomen dubium in
   accordance with previous authors. Additionally, two new ocellated
   species of Potamotrygon from the Parana-Paraguay basin are described:
   Potamotrygon pantanensis, sp. nov. and Potamotrygon amandae, sp. nov.
   These are described and compared with P. motoro and other congeners.
   Potamotrygon pantanensis, sp. nov. is described from the northern
   Pantanal region; Potamotrygon amandae, sp. nov. is widespread in the
   Parana-Paraguay basin.
C1 Loboda, Thiago Silva; Univ Sao Paulo, Inst Biociencias, Rua Matao,Trav
   14,101, Sao Paulo, BR-05508090 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM loboda_bio@yahoo.com.br
RI Loboda, Thiago S/I-4231-2018

   name; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America

   basin / Systematics].

TI New species of miniature fish from Marajo Island, Para, Brazil, with
   comments on its relationships (Characiformes: Characidae).
AU Marinho, Manoela M.F. (manumfm@yahoo.com.br) 
   Bastos, Douglas A.
   Menezes, Naercio A.

VL 11

PS 739-746
PD Dec 27 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB A new miniature species of the family Characidae from Marajo Island,
   Para State, Brazil is described and assigned to the genus Tyttobrycon.
   The new species can be distinguished from its congeners primarily by
   having multicuspid teeth on jaws, and additionally by having the
   combination of 5-7 premaxillary teeth, dorsal fin only with scattered
   melanophores and the presence of an adipose fin.

DT Article
TI A new species of the characid genus Hollandichthys Eigenmann from
   coastal rivers of southern Brazil (Teleostei: Characiformes) with a
   discussion on the diagnosis of the genus.
AU Bertaco, Vinicius A. (vbertaco@gmail.com) 
   Malabarba, Luiz R.
SO Neotropical Ichthyology
VL 11
IS 4
PS 767-778
PD Dec 27 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Hollandichthys taramandahy, new species, is described from the rio
   Tramanda, rio Mampituba, and rio Ararangua basins, coastal drainages of
   Rio Grande do Sul and Santa Catarina States, Brazil. The new species is
   distinguished from H. multifasciatus, the single recognized species of
   the genus, by the presence of a small black spot covering the base of
   median caudal-fin rays, by the lower number of dorsal and ventral
   procurrent caudal-fin rays, by the absence of a black spot located along
   anterior half of adipose-fin, and by the absence of humeral spot in
   specimens larger than 60 mm of standard length. Comments about the
   geographic distribution and diagnosis are provided for the genus.

TI Harttia absaberi, a new species of loricariid catfish (Siluriformes:
   Loricariidae: Loricariinae) from the upper rio Parana basin, Brazil.
AU Oyakawa, Osvaldo Takeshi (ilana-fic@gmail.com) 
   Fichberg, Ilana
   Langeani, Francisco
SO Neotropical Ichthyology
VL 11
IS 4
PS 779-786
PD Dec 27 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new species of Harttia, tribe Harttiini, is described from tributaries
   of upper portions of rio Parana drainage. The new species, the smallest
   known species of the genus, attaining up to 74.0 mm of standard length,
   can be distinguished from its congeners by the combination of the
   following characters: abdomen completely covered by plates, a single
   preanal plate, plates of the gular area in broad contact with the canal
   plate. Harttia absaberi is the second species of the genus known from
   the upper portion of rio Parana drainage.

TI Parotocinclus seridoensis, a new hypoptopomatine catfish (Siluriformes:
   Loricariidae) from the upper rio Piranhas-Acu basin, northeastern
   Brazil.
AU Ramos, Telton Pedro A. (telton@gmail.com) 
   Barros-Neto, Luciano F.
   Britski, Heraldo A.
   Lima, Sergio M.Q.
SO Neotropical Ichthyology
VL 11
IS 4
PS 787-796
PD Dec 27 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB A new species of Parotocinclus is described from the upper rio
   Piranhas-Acu basin, northeastern Brazil. The new species differs from
   all its congeners, except P. bidentatus, P. muriaensis (both from rio
   Paraiba do Sul basin, southeastern Brazil), and P. spilurus (rio
   Jaguaribe basin, northeastern Brazil) by presenting the adipose fin
   rudimentary or absent. The new species differs from P. bidentatus, P.
   muriaensis, and P. spilurus mainly by presenting the abdomen region
   extensively naked, with few reduced rounded dermal platelets between the
   pectoral girdle and the anus. Parotocinclus seridoensis is probably an
   endemic species of the semi-arid Caatinga, region where the genus
   presents high species richness.
C1 Ramos, Telton Pedro A.; Univ Fed Rio Grande Norte, Dept Bot Ecol & Zool,
   Natal, RN, BR-59978970 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM telton@gmail.com

DT Article
TI Centromochlus meridionalis, a new catfish species from the southern
   Amazonian limits, Mato Grosso State, Brazil (Siluriformes:
   Auchenipteridae).
AU Sarmento-Soares, Luisa Maria (luisa@nossosriachos.net) 
   Cabeceira, Fernando G.
   Carvalho, Lucelia Nobre
   Zuanon, Jansen
   Akama, Alberto
SO Neotropical Ichthyology
VL 11
IS 4
PS 797-808
PD Dec 27 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Centromochlus actually comprises eleven species, being the most
   problematic genus among the Centromochlinae, including morphologically
   heterogeneous taxa. The Centromochlus species have a wide distributional
   area on northern South America. Centromochlus meridionalis, new species,
   is described from headwaters of rio Teles Pires, contributor of rio
   Tapajos, Mato Grosso State, Brazil, and represents one of the
   southernmost records of a centromochlin catfish for Meridional Amazon
   rivers. Centromochlus meridionalis is promptly distinguished from its
   congeners by the small orbital diameter (relative to head length), and
   also by the combination of absence of first nuchal plate, anterior
   margin of dorsal-fin spine smooth, six branched rays in anal fin, seven
   pairs of ribs and 34 vertebrae. They are small sized catfishes with
   adults between 33 to 61 mm in standard length. The modified male anal
   fin is conspicuous, with the third unbranched ray enlarged, about twice
   the width of first unbranched ray. The new species inhabits a region
   strongly endangered by environmental changes due to expansion of
   agropecuary activities on Brazilian Amazon, which include this species
   in an uncertain situation regarding the conservation status of its
   natural population.
C1 Sarmento-Soares, Luisa Maria; Museu Biol Prof Mello Leitao, Av Jose
   Ruschi 4, Santa Teresa, ES, BR-29650000 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM luisa@nossosriachos.net

   Lucelia/D-5986-2013
OI Soares, Luisa Sarmento/0000-0002-8621-1794; Nobre Carvalho,
   Lucelia/0000-0002-0673-0165

DT Article
TI A new species of dwarf sea bass, genus Serranus (Serranidae:
   Actinopterygii), from the southwestern Atlantic Ocean.
AU Carvalho Filho, Alfredo (alfie@telnet.com.br) 
   Leite Ferreira, Carlos Eduardo
SO Neotropical Ichthyology
VL 11
IS 4
PS 809-814
PD Dec 27 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Serranus aliceae n. sp. is described from Rio de Janeiro and Espirito
   Santo States, southeastern Brazilian coast. The species is readily
   distinguished from its congeners by the following combination of
   characters: scales around the caudal peduncle 20 or 21; total gill
   rakers on first branchial arch 23-29; cheek-scales rows 5 or 6; and by
   the coloration of live specimens, which are reddish with a broad,
   conspicuous, white stripe from post-orbital region to the caudal-fin
   base and a white abdomen. The new species apparently inhabits the deeper
   (30 or more meters) portions of reef environments along the subtropical
   Brazilian coast, and is possibly associated with upwelling cold-water
   masses. The species was observed hovering above rocky bottoms, feeding
   on micro-crustaceans, squid larvae, and zooplankton. This new species
   increases to eight the number of valid Serranus species recorded in the
   southwestern Atlantic.
C1 Carvalho Filho, Alfredo; Fish Bizz Ltd, Rua Moncorvo Filho 51, Sao
   Paulo, BR-05424070 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM alfie@telnet.com.br

AN ZOOR15110064474
DT Article
TI OXFORDIAN BELEMNITES AND AMMONITES FROM ROSTAM KOLA, NORTHERN EAST
   ALBORZ, NORTH IRAN.
AU Mariotti, Nino (nino.mariotti@uniroma1.it) 
   Weis, Robert
   Falahatgar, Mostafa
   Parent, Horacio
   Javidan, Mojtaba
SO Boletin del Instituto de Fisiografia y Geologia Universidad Nacional de
   Rosario
VL 83
PS 15-26
PD Dec 27 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A Middle Oxfordian Jurassic belemnite fauna, associated with ammonites,
   from the Lar Formation at Rostam Kola (North Iran) is described for the
   first time. The specimens have been assigned to the following taxa:
   Hibolithes hastatus, Hibolithes aff. beyrichi, Pachybelemnopsis
   latesulcatus, Duvalia didayana, Duvalia monsalvensis, Rhopaloteuthis cf.
   argoviana and Rhopaloteuthis sauvanausa. Ammonites collected from the
   same belemnite bearing levels allow to refer the belemnite fauna to the
   Middle Oxfordian Transversarium Zone. Only a few Tethyan belemnite
   assemblages are recorded in the Middle Oxfordian, but it is possible to
   establish a close affinity with the taxa of the Mediterranean Province.
   The ammonites associated with the belemnites as also those from the
   upper levels of the section show clear Submediterranean affinities. All
   the ammonites known from previous and present surveys in the study area
   belong to the families Perisphinctidae and Ataxioceratidae. The species
   in new samples are Perisphinctes cf. parandieri, Perisphinctes
   (Subdiscosphinctes) sp. A, Orthosphinctes sp. A, Orthosphinctes sp. B,
   Lithacosphinctes? sp. A and Passendorferia cf. gygii.
C1 Mariotti, Nino; Univ La Sapienza, Dipartimento Sci Terra, Ple A Moro 5,
   Rome, I-00185, Italy, Italy.
EM nino.mariotti@uniroma1.it
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1666-115X

   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   [Zoogeography / Palaeogeography / ] [Iran / Alborz Mountains, east /
   stratigraphical distribution] [Jurassic / Middle Oxfordian / ].
